It was created in 2005 to honor author Andre Norton. Any type of science fiction or fantasy book, even graphic novels, can be nominated as long as it's for kids. There's no word count limit and it's awarded at the same time as the Nebula Awards. You can even be nominated for both!

These people use art to work with spirits. Sierra must learn about her family's special powers and protect her community from a bad guy stealing their magic, all while fighting against gentrification.

The first book was first published by a small company called Chicken House, later owned by Scholastic. They published the rest and also re-released the first one. It started in 1950 when Nova Publications launched it alongside their New Worlds magazine. Walter Gillings initially edited the first two issues, but John Carnell took over as editor to save costs. Carnell worked on both magazines until Nova closed in 1964. Roberts & Vinter then bought the magazines, and Kyril Bonfiglioli became the editor of Science Fantasy, renaming it Impulse later that year. Question: Are the Laleli Mosque and Esma Sultan Mansion located in the same neighborhood? 

 Passage: 
The Laleli Mosque, also known as the Tulip Mosque, is an old Ottoman mosque from the 18th century. It can be found in the Laleli area of Fatih, Istanbul, Turkey. 
The Esma Sultan Mansion is a historic mansion by the Bosphorus in Istanbul's Ortaköy area. It was once owned by Esma Sultan and has been renovated to become a cultural center now.
Esma Sultan was born on March 21, 1873, and was a princess from the Ottoman Empire. She was the child of Sultan Abdülaziz and Gevheri Kadın, who is the mother of Salih Bey Svatnba. Esma had a unique connection as she was the half-sister of the last Caliph of the Muslim world, Abdülmecid II. 
The Great Mosque of Algiers, also known as Djama'a al-Kebir or Grand Mosque d'Alger, is a historic mosque in Algiers, Algeria, close to the harbor. Built in 1097, it's one of the oldest mosques in the city and in Algeria, after Sidi Okba Mosque. It showcases Almoravid architecture and has a minaret dating back to 1332 (or 1324), built by a Tlemcen Sultan. The mosque's gallery was added in 1840 following French reconstruction of the street. 
Küçük Hüseyin Pasha, an important Ottoman leader and navy chief, served as the Grand Admiral from March 11, 1792, until his death on December 7, 1803. He was part of the Ottoman royal family because he married Esma Sultan, an Ottoman princess. 
Esma Sultan, born on July 17, 1778, and passed away on June 4, 1848, was a princess from the Ottoman Empire. She was the daughter of Sultan Abdul Hamid I and had two brothers, Sultan Mustafa IV and Sultan Mahmud II. Esma took on the roles of adopting and being the mother to Bezmiâlem Sultan and Rahime Perestu Sultan. 
The Sultan Ahmed Mosque, also called the Blue Mosque, is an important historic mosque in Istanbul, Turkey. It's a popular tourist spot and still used for prayers by men. Built between 1609 and 1616, it was made during Sultan Ahmed I's time. The mosque has beautiful blue tiles inside and shines blue at night with lights around its five big domes, six tall minarets, and eight smaller domes. It's close to another famous place called the Hagia Sophia. 
Esma Sultan is the name shared by daughters of three different Ottoman Sultans. 
Gevheri Kadın, born on July 8, 1856, and passed away on September 6, 1884, was the fifth wife of Sultan Abdülaziz, who reigned during the 32nd Ottoman era. She is known for being the mother of Şehzade Mehmed Seyfeddin and Esma Sultan, both prominent figures in the Ottoman Empire. 
Esma Sultan was a princess from the Ottoman Empire. She was born on March 14, 1726, and her father was Sultan Ahmed III. Her mother's name was Zeynep Kadın. Esma had two half-brothers: Sultan Mustafa III and Abdul Hamid I.

output: No, the Laleli Mosque and Esma Sultan Mansion are not located in the same neighborhood. The Laleli Mosque is in the Laleli area of Fatih, while the Esma Sultan Mansion is in the Ortaköy area.**

Question: Aside from the Apple Remote, what other device can control the program Apple Remote was originally designed to interact with? 

 Passage: 
Apple released a remote control called the Apple Remote in 2005 to control their products that use infrared technology. It was first made for the Front Row media program on the iSight iMac G5 and works with some later Macs too. The first three versions of Apple TV used this remote, but it was replaced by the Siri Remote in the fourth generation. Before the Apple Remote, Apple made simple IR remotes for things like the Macintosh TV and PowerCD drive. 
Front Row is a program that used to let Mac computers and Apple TV watch and play videos, pictures, music, and podcasts. It worked with iTunes and iPhoto, and you could control it with a remote or keyboard. The first version came out in 2005, but they stopped making updates for it in Mac OS X 10.7.
A universal remote is a versatile remote that can control different brands of electronic devices. Basic universal remotes can only control a certain number of devices based on the manufacturer's limit, but more advanced ones let you add new devices by programming them. Often, when you buy a remote for one device, it might also work with other gadgets. For example, you can use a VCR remote to control various TV brands. 
A remote control is a small device that lets you control electronic things, like a TV or DVD player, from far away. It's useful when the device is too far to reach or when you want to operate something like a garage door or projector without standing up. It makes things easier and more comfortable for the person using it. . This new remote replaces the old Apple Remote and can even be used with the Apple TV 4K. Tim Cook, the CEO, talked about it during an Apple event. 
NetSupport Manager is a remote control software that works on multiple platforms like Windows, Mac, Linux, Solaris, and mobile devices. It lets you control and manage other devices from a Windows or Windows Mobile device. The software first came out in 1989 for DOS networks. It's great because it lets you see thumbnails of many remote systems and switch between them easily, like a keyboard and mouse for multiple computers. You can also transfer files, chat, and check hardware and software on the remote devices. It has less functionality for Linux and Mac users. In 2012, they added support for iOS and Android tablets and phones, as well as a version for Macs. They released a new version in 2013 that added support for ChromeOS too. Both the controlling device and the device being controlled need to have NetSupport Manager installed before you can use it. 
Apple Watch is a smartwatch made by Apple. It helps you track fitness and health, works with iPhones and other Apple things. You need an iPhone 5 or later with iOS 8.2 or later to use it. First, there were four types: Sport, regular, fancy Hermès, and a fancy Edition. The watch connects to your iPhone wirelessly for calls and texts. It became very popular when it came out in 2015, selling 4.2 million in the first half of that year. Apple released a new version in 2016 with two types, Series 2 and an older Series 1. Then, in 2017, they made the Series 3. 
MacScan is a security tool made for Apple's Mac OS X by SecureMac. It helps protect your computer from bad stuff like spyware, harmful software, and tracking cookies. It was the first of its kind for Macs. It also checks for programs that let others control your computer remotely, like Apple Remote Desktop, so you can make sure they're only there when you want them to be. 
Lionel's Trainmaster Command (TMCC) is an electronic system for controlling O scale model trains, mainly used from 1994 to 2006. It's similar to Digital Command Control (DCC), which is standard for HO scale trains. TMCC has an advantage because it can work with non-TMCC trains, including LionChief and LionChief Plus. MTH's DCS controller can also control TMCC trains, and all systems can be on the same track without needing separate voltages.

TMCC and Legacy send signals to the train's antenna, identifying the locomotive by number and controlling features like speed, sounds, and lighting. DCS does this by transmitting a carrier through the rails. TMCC/Legacy remotes send commands through a separate device, while LionChief/LionChief+ locos have built-in remotes that work directly with the train.

In 2017, Lionel introduced a universal remote for LionChief+ that can control up to three trains at once, making it easier to manage multiple trains. 
Apple Remote Desktop is a program created by Apple that helps people in charge of many computers or teachers who need to help others or show things to groups. It lets you control or watch other computers from your own computer through a network, starting from March 14, 2002. It replaced an older tool called Apple Network Assistant.

output: A universal remote, like the Lionell's universal remote for LionChief+ or the VCR remote that can control various TV brands, can control the program Apple Remote was originally designed to interact with, which is Front Row.

Louise Bryant was a journalist, activist, and feminist who is famous for her support of Russia and the Bolsheviks during the Russian Revolution. Alexander Kerensky was a Russian lawyer who played a significant role in the 1917 Revolution. After that, Kerensky lived in exile in Paris and New York City, working for the Hoover Institution until his death in 1970.

Unfortunately, Ethiopia was occupied by Italy from 1936 to 1941, but it was eventually freed by British and Ethiopian forces.

His research focused on political leadership, community organization, ethnohistory, and culture. He wrote a book, initially titled A Galla Monarchy, examining the monarchy's structure, the ruler's power, and its origins. In his 1965-66 study, he concentrated on the role of spirit mediums, k'allu, in organizing religious activities, resolving conflicts, and providing informal political leadership in rural areas. Italy agreed to cancel the Treaty of Wuchale and acknowledged Ethiopia as an independent nation.

It was named after Felix Dzerzhinsky, an important person in Soviet history who started the Soviet secret police, which we now call the Cheka.

The Kargil War Memorial, also called Vijaypath, is a special building made by the Indian Army in Dras, close to the Tiger Hill. It's about 5 kilometers from the main part of the city and on a road called Srinagar-Leh National Highway 1D. This memorial is to remember the brave soldiers and officers who lost their lives during the 1999 war between India and Pakistan, which became known as the Kargil War. There's a big wall with the names of all the heroes, and on Kargil Vijay Diwas, which is on July 26th, the Prime Minister of India honors them too, at a place called Amar Jawan Jyothi in New Delhi. At the memorial, you can see the mountains the Indian Army took back from Pakistan and even buy souvenirs. They also flew a giant flag, 15 kilograms heavy, to celebrate their 13th victory anniversary. 
The Devon County War Memorial is a special monument built to remember the people from Devon who fought and died in World War 1. It was made by a famous designer named Sir Edwin Lutyens and is located in Exeter, which is the main town in Devon, England. This memorial is one of 15 similar designs by Lutyens and is unique because it also honors the city's war heroes. 

At first, people wanted to finish building a cloister at Exeter Cathedral for this purpose, but they didn't have enough money. So, they asked Lutyens to make a different kind of memorial, called a War Cross. They picked a spot on the cathedral's green after looking at many places. At the same time, there was a plan for a separate memorial in a different garden. Because the committees didn't work together, Exeter has two war memorials: one by the cathedral and another in Northernhay Gardens. 
The Manchester Cenotaph is a memorial built by Sir Edwin Lutyens in St Peter's Square, England, to honor soldiers from the First World War and later conflicts. Manchester took longer than most cities to decide on a memorial, only starting in 1922. The committee collected £10,000 quickly but choosing the right spot was difficult. People wanted to put it in Albert Square but that meant moving statues, which artists didn't like. Then, Piccadilly Gardens was considered, but the council chose St Peter's Square because it was easier. There was already a memorial cross there, but they couldn't move it, so the cenotaph was built around it. 
The York City War Memorial is a memorial from World War 1 designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens. It is in York, England. Plans for the memorial started in 1919, but people had different ideas. They first wanted it to be useful, but later decided on a monument. The city engineer gave an estimate, and the committee chose Lutyens, who was also working on a memorial for the North Eastern Railway (NER) in York. Lutyens made a design, but people didn't like how it looked with the old buildings and thought the NER's memorial would be too big. They changed the location and Lutyens made a simpler design, but they couldn't afford the full plan, so they only built a War Cross. 
The Spalding War Memorial is a special monument built in the gardens of Ayscoughfee Hall in Spalding, Lincolnshire, England. It was made to remember people who fought in World War 1. A lady named Barbara McLaren, whose husband was a local leader who died in the war, wanted to build a memorial. She asked a famous architect, Sir Edwin Lutyens, to design it. The idea was for a big cloister with a round pond in the middle and a cross. The memorial would be in the beautiful gardens of Ayscoughfee Hall, which was owned by the local government. At first, people had different ideas, but after a meeting and a vote in 1919, they chose a smaller version of her original plan, and also added a clock on the town's corn exchange building. 
The Forbury Hotel, which used to be called Shire Hall, is a special hotel in the center of Reading, a town in Berkshire, England. It is located right next to a public park called Forbury Gardens on its sunny side. 
St James's Church is a Catholic church in the middle of Reading, Berkshire. It's next to the old Reading Abbey ruins, between Forbury Gardens and Reading Gaol. 
Forbury Gardens is a park in Reading, Berkshire, England. It was once the outer part of Reading Abbey, where the church stood. People used to have fairs there every few years until the 1800s. The area was once called The Forbury and still has a road with that name.

The rulers sometimes acted independently, but often answered to overlords in Norway, Ireland, England, Scotland, or Orkney. There were also disagreements about who owned what part of the land. Jaluit Atoll is a big coral island group in the Pacific Ocean with 91 islands. It's part of the Marshall Islands and has a special area called a legislative district. The Ralik Chain is nearby. The Lewis lamp is a special light used in big, tall buildings called lighthouses. A man named Winslow Lewis made it in 1810 and it's better than older lamps because it uses less oil. It looks a bit like another lamp called the Argand lamp, but has a round mirror behind it and a big, green glass lens in front. Another version with a mirror was made by Aimé Argand, but the United States chose Lewis' design for their lighthouses.
A hollow-cathode lamp (HCL) is a special lamp used in science to make light with specific colors (for testing atoms) and to control the frequency of lasers. It works better than a normal cold cathode lamp because it has a empty space inside the cathode, which lets more electricity flow at lower voltage. 
Antoine Quinquet, a French pharmacist, was born in Soissons on March 9, 1745. He started as an apprentice in an apothecary in his hometown in 1760. In 1777, he relocated to Paris and worked for Antoine Baumé. During his time in Geneva, he met Aimé Argand. Upon his return to Paris in 1779, he opened his very own pharmacy. 
A kerosene lamp, also known as a paraffin lamp in some places, is a simple lighting device that burns kerosene (paraffin) to produce light. It has a wick or a special material (mantle) inside a glass chimney or globe. These lamps can be placed on tables or used as portable hand-held lanterns. They are useful when there's no electricity, like in areas without power, during blackouts, at outdoor activities like camping, and on boats. There are three main types: flat wick for portable ones, central draught (round wick), and mantle lamp. The portable kerosene lanterns have a flat wick and come in different versions for different flame control. 
A glow switch starter is a device used with fluorescent lamps to help them start. It has neon or argon gas inside and has a bimetallic strip and a fixed electrode. When electricity flows, the gas heats the strip, making it bend towards the electrode, which connects the lamp. This helps the lamp start. After a while, the strip cools and disconnects, repeating until the lamp lights up. However, when the lamp gets old, the starter might keep turning on and off rapidly until it fails or the lamp's electrode burns out. 
The qulliq is a special lamp that Arctic people, like the Inuit, Chukchi, and Yupik, have used for a long time. It's made from things like seal oil, blubber, or soapstone. 
A trouble light is a special lamp that shines light in hard-to-see areas and can handle some rough treatment. It has a bulb inside a strong case with a handle, which makes it one piece. The cord is long so you can reach far, and sometimes there's an electrical outlet on the handle, so it can also be used as an extension cord. 
The Hefner lamp, also known as Hefnerkerze in German, is a special lamp used in studying light that burns a substance called amyl acetate. 
Nikola Tesla invented the carbon button lamp, a simple lamp with a tiny carbon ball inside a glass bulb with no air. It needs special high-frequency electricity to create an electric arc, which heats the carbon and makes it glow. Surprisingly, this lamp can also produce harmful rays.

The 1999 Odisha cyclone was a very strong and destructive tropical cyclone that happened in the North Indian Ocean. It started as a tropical depression in the Andaman Sea on October 25th, but actually formed from storms in the Sulu Sea four days earlier. It intensified to Category 4 and then Category 5 before weakening due to wind shear and upwelling. The storm then weakened further and moved south, becoming a tropical low before dissipating completely by May 16th. 
In 1988, a powerful storm called Severe Tropical Cyclone Anne formed in the South Pacific. It started as a weak depression near Tuvalu and then grew stronger as it moved southwest. On January 8, it became a named storm called Anne. Just one day later, it rapidly intensified and became the strongest storm to hit Vanuatu in four years. Anne reached its strongest point on January 11, matching the intensity of a Category 5 hurricane and a Category 4 cyclone. It then moved south and hit New Caledonia, making it the strongest storm ever to affect that area. After interacting with another storm called Tropical Cyclone Agi, Anne weakened and became a depression. Its last known location was southeast of New Caledonia on January 14. 
In the 2007-08 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season, Tropical Cyclone Hondo was the strongest and longest-lasting storm. It started as a tropical disturbance in early February, east-southeast of Diego Garcia. It quickly became a moderate storm, then a severe one, and reached its peak intensity with winds of 130 mph on February 7th. However, it weakened over the next few days due to faster speed and cooler waters. Hondo disappeared on February 12th but regained strength and was named Ex-Hondo, becoming a tropical depression. It passed over Réunion, causing it to weaken again. The storm dissipated on February 29th after looping counterclockwise.

It started as a cluster of clouds in the eastern Arabian Sea on June 1 and rapidly gained strength due to favorable conditions and warm water. By June 4, it reached its peak with winds blowing at 235 km/h (145 mph). However, as it met dry air and cooler water, its intensity decreased. Initially, Kesiny moved southeast but changed direction due to a stronger weather ridge. It intensified into a cyclone on May 6 but weakened later. The sarod is a stringed instrument from India, often used in classical music. It's similar to the sitar but has a deeper, more thoughtful sound. The sarod also has special strings that give it a nice, full sound. It can slide between notes easily, which is important in Indian music.

The sousaphone is a special brass instrument similar to the tuba, invented in 1893 by J.W. Pepper for famous bandleader John Philip Sousa. It was made to be easier to play while standing or walking, and its bell points forward to send the music above the band. It's shaped like a circle around the player and is great for marching bands and other music styles. Earlier, they were made of brass, but now they can also be made of lighter materials like fiberglass. 
A bukkehorn, also known as a bockhorn or Billy Goat Horn, is an old instrument from Scandinavia made from a ram or goat's horn. The horn is usually taken from a goat 5 to 7 years before it's turned into an instrument. It was commonly used by shepherds and milkmaids in the mountain farms during summer to communicate or scare away animals. As it gained finger holes, people could play music with it. There are two ways to blow it: mostly like a trumpet or sometimes like a clarinet. 
An experimental musical instrument is a unique or custom-made instrument that either changes or adds to an existing one, or creates a new type altogether. It can be made by altering regular instruments with simple fixes, like adding objects to a piano, using household items like a tub stopper for brass, or combining acoustic and electronic parts to make something new and different. 
Udaka Vadya is an Indian musical instrument, similar to the Jal tarang. It is a percussion instrument that produces sound by striking a surface and falls under the category of Ghan Vadya in medieval music texts. This instrument has historical references in Vatsyayana's Kamasutra and the 17th-century Sangeeta Parijata. Learning to play Udaka Vadya was considered essential for women, as it was one of the 64 skills they were expected to master. 
The keyboard glockenspiel is an instrument that works like a piano but plays the sound of a glockenspiel. It was first used in Handel's Saul in 1739 and later in other compositions. Mozart used a similar instrument called a strumento d'acciaio in The Magic Flute, and Ravel liked the keyboard version for its bright and colorful sound in orchestral pieces. Nowadays, there are also larger versions with pedals, made by Bergerault, that can handle the wide range of notes in modern music. 
An asset class is a collection of financial instruments that share similar features and behave similarly in the market. These can be divided into real assets and financial assets. Most instruments within the same class follow the same laws and rules, but there can be exceptions. For example, futures contracts related to an asset belong to the same class as the original asset but have separate regulations. 
Accompaniment is the music that helps support the main parts of a song, like the melody or main theme. It comes in many different forms depending on the type of music. In simple music, like pop, the main voice has chords playing softly in the background. The accompaniment usually gives the beat and shows the order of the chords. You can hear this in songs on instruments like piano, organ, or guitar. If there's only one musician, they might use a keyboard or guitar because they can play chords and bass at the same time. Singers can even play along with themselves on guitar or piano, and sometimes, they use their voice and body to create the accompaniment, like Bobby McFerrin does.

Question: Which author has won more Pulitzer Prizes, Thomas Friedman or Henri Bergson? 

 Passage: 
Henri-Louis Bergson was a French philosopher who had a significant impact, particularly during the early 1900s and after World War II, on the philosophical thoughts of Europe. 
Thomas Friedman is a renowned American journalist and author who has won the prestigious Pulitzer Prize three times. He was born on July 20, 1953.
Introduction to Metaphysics is a 1903 essay by Henri Bergson. He talks about reality not as separate parts, but like a flowing process, similar to ideas from process philosophy or Greek philosopher Heraclitus. Bergson believes reality is too complex to understand fully by breaking it down into tiny pieces. Instead, he thinks we can truly grasp reality by using our intuition, which means connecting with it on a deeper level, like 'entering' the object. 
Duration, as explained by French philosopher Henri Bergson, is a concept he developed to understand time and consciousness better. Bergson believed that Herbert Spencer's ideas were incomplete because Spencer didn't fully grasp mechanics. Bergson felt that time is something that can't be measured or explained by math or science, because when we try to measure it, it's already gone. Time can seem to move faster or slower for each person, but for scientists, it remains constant.

Bergson focused on the personal experience of time, which he called duration. This is a unique, unquantifiable aspect of our lives that cannot be fully described or captured by words or images. To understand duration, one must use their imagination to grasp it intuitively, as it's something that can only be felt, not fully explained. 
Samuel Eliot Morison was a well-known American historian who specialized in maritime and American history. He earned his PhD from Harvard in 1912 and taught there for 40 years. Morison won Pulitzer Prizes for his biographies of Christopher Columbus and John Paul Jones. He also wrote a comprehensive history of US naval operations during World War II, published in 15 volumes between 1947 and 1962. Morison authored the popular Oxford History of the American People and co-wrote The Growth of the American Republic with Henry Steele Commager. Throughout his life, he received numerous honors, including honorary degrees, literary awards, military commendations, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom, among others. 
On April 18, 2011, the Pulitzer Prizes were announced. The Los Angeles Times and The New York Times each won two awards, with the former receiving the top honor for Public Service. Surprisingly, no prize was given in the Breaking News category. The Wall Street Journal won after a four-year break since 2007. Jennifer Egan's A Visit From the Goon Squad, which had previously won the 2010 National Book Critics Circle Award, won the Fiction prize. Notably, Carol Guzy from The Washington Post made history by being the first journalist to win four Pulitzer Prizes. 
In his 1907 book Creative Evolution, French philosopher Henri Bergson introduced the concept of Élan vital. He used it to discuss how things, especially living organisms, grow and develop on their own without any external guidance. Bergson believed this vital force was connected to consciousness, like how we feel and experience things, and the inner sense of time passing. Some people call it vital impetus or vital force when they don't agree with Bergson's ideas. 
Time and Free Will is a book written by Henri Bergson when he was a PhD student. It came out in 1889. The book talks about the idea of free will, which many philosophers have trouble with. Bergson believes that this confusion happens because people wrongly connect things that are not extended, like thoughts, with things that are extended, like actions. His theory about time, called duration, became very popular among thinkers in Europe later on. 
Moina Mathers, an artist and believer in the occult, lived during the early 1900s. She had a famous brother, Henri Bergson, who was a Jewish philosopher and won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1927. Moina is best known for marrying Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mathers, a key member of the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn. Matter and Memory is a book by philosopher Henri Bergson from 1896. It discusses the connection between the body and spirit, focusing on memory as a way to understand this relationship. Bergson wrote this in response to Théodule Ribot's book, which said that memory is a material part of the brain. Bergson disagreed, believing memory is spiritual and helps guide our actions. He thought that brain problems could affect memory's usefulness, but not erase it completely. Memories just don't work properly when they're not fully realized in the brain.

The Clock Tower, also known as the Jubilee Clock Tower, is a famous clock tower located in the heart of Brighton, a city in England. People in Brighton have a sentimental connection to it, but opinions differ on whether it's a beautiful building or not. The Galle Clock Tower, also known as the Anthonisz Memorial Clock Tower, is a well-known landmark situated inside Galle Fort in Galle, Sri Lanka. On June 22, 1954, the Azam Mosque was officially started during a religious ceremony. This was the birthday of Ali al-Ridha, the eighth Imam in Shia Islam. It is the third well-preserved mosque in Plovdiv, following the Dzhumaya Mosque and Imaret Mosque. The Nashville Terminal Subdivision is a rail line owned by CSX Transportation in Tennessee. It's divided into five parts in Nashville. The northern part starts in Madison, near the southern end of the Ex-L&N Mainline Subdivision. The line is double tracked for 22 miles to Brentwood. At a location called Johnny Cash Amqui, the Evansville, Indiana line meets the terminal. There are two locations with crossings, Williams Ave and Nesbitt Lane. The line continues to Ekin and the Nashville National Cemetery, where it has a crossover track. From there, it goes to Maplewood, a major spot for crew swapping and the Radnor Cutoff, which provides direct access to Radnor yard for trains to Louisville and Chicago. The Cutoff ends at Shelby Park, passing the Shelby bridge before converging back to double track. Further south, the terminal meets the L&N mainline at Chicken Pike. The mainline has two tracks, A-1 for Chattanooga and Atlanta, and A-2 for Memphis and other destinations. The Wye track connects to the Bruceton side, mostly used for local trains. The line eventually reaches Kayne Ave, a busy hub, where the Memphis Subdivision joins. The terminal splits into the Chattanooga Subdivision and continues to Brentwood, where it becomes a single track before joining the S&NA North and Nashville Subdivisions. The Nashville Terminal Subdivision is a crucial part of the CSX network.

Thomas Berger's 1964 novel, Little Big Man, is a satirical take on the western genre, also classified as picaresque fiction. This book, often considered Berger's masterpiece, was later adapted into a well-received film by Arthur Penn. Sindhi folktales are a significant part of the culture in southern Pakistan, especially in the Sindh province. These fairy tales and stories make up the folklore of the area. Because Romeo kills Juliet's cousin in a fight, he has to leave town. He sadly ends his life after thinking Juliet is dead, but she was not. 
Benvolio is a character in the play Romeo and Juliet. He is related to both Romeo and Montague - Romeo's cousin and Montague's nephew. In the story, Benvolio tries to stop the fighting between the Capulet and Montague families, but unfortunately, he isn't successful.
Hamlet is the main character in Shakespeare's play Hamlet. He is the prince of Denmark and wants to avenge his father's murder by Claudius, who took over the throne. Hamlet is confused and questioning his own mind throughout the story. In the end, he ends up causing the deaths of many people, including his father's enemies, two friends, his girlfriend Ophelia, and even his own mother, who died accidentally. 
Macbeth is a play by William Shakespeare, first acted in 1606. The story shows how political greed can harm people emotionally and physically. This play best represents Shakespeare's relationship with King James I, who supported his theater group. Macbeth was later printed in 1623 and is the shortest tragedy written by Shakespeare. 
Revenge tragedy, also known as revenge dramas or tragedies of blood, were popular plays in early modern England. Ashley H. Thorndike defined this genre in 1902, explaining that revenge tragedies are focused on revenge as the main motive and involve the pursuit of revenge, often resulting in the deaths of the murderers and sometimes the avenger. The Spanish Tragedy by Thomas Kyd (1580s) is often seen as the first example, but research now suggests that revenge tragedies existed even earlier, around 1560, with plays like Jasper Heywood's translations of Seneca's works and Gorbuduc by Thomases Norton and Sackville. Shakespeare's Hamlet (1599-1602), Titus Andronicus (1588-1593), and Thomas Middleton's The Revenger's Tragedy (1606) are also well-known examples of this genre. 
Shakespearean tragedy refers to the majority of tragic plays written by William Shakespeare. Although some of his historical plays are considered tragedies due to their tragic elements, they are classified as histories because they are based on real events in English history. On the other hand, plays like Julius Caesar, Antony and Cleopatra, and Coriolanus, which have historical settings but foreign sources, are mostly categorized as tragedies. Later in his career, Shakespeare wrote tragicomic plays, a mix of tragedy and comedy, with a tragic hero but a happy ending, similar to his comedies. Scholar F.S. Boas introduced the concept of problem plays, which don't fit neatly into either tragedy or comedy, due to their unique themes, settings, or endings. Even today, experts sometimes argue about how to classify certain of Shakespeare's plays. 
Rory Williams is a character from the popular British TV show Doctor Who. He was introduced in the 5th series and became a friend, or companion, of the main character, the Doctor, played by Matt Smith. Rory was originally worried because he thought his girlfriend Amy, who was also with the Doctor, loved the Doctor more than him. But later on, he became a brave hero and got married to Amy. They even had a baby together, but sadly, their baby was taken away. Rory and Amy found out that their friend River Song was actually their daughter. Juliet Capulet is the main female character in William Shakespeare's play Romeo and Juliet. She is the only child of her family, the Capulets, and falls in love with Romeo, who comes from a rival family called the Montagues. This love story has been around for a very long time, even before Shakespeare wrote about it.

Anna first appeared on April 10, 1985, as a fence. She was created by Gloria Monty and some other writers. She is Robert Scorpio's ex-wife and competes with his other wife, Holly. Anabolic steroids are a type of hormone, similar to testosterone, that helps build muscles and gives men their manly traits like deep voices and body hair. They help in growing tissues, especially muscles, and are in the same group as hormones like estrogen and progesterone. The word anabolic comes from the Greek meaning to build up. 
Anabolic steroids, which come from the male hormone testosterone, are used to help build muscles and increase strength. People use them for looks and to perform better in sports and bodybuilding. These drugs make muscles grow faster than natural workouts. Teenagers and adults often use them because they speed up muscle growth.
Docking is when someone cuts off the tail or sometimes even the ears of an animal. We usually call it cropping for ears and docking for tails, but sometimes people also use tailing. The word comes from dock, which means the part of the tail where the hairs grow. 
Tensile testing is a crucial materials science test where a material is pulled until it breaks. This test helps choose the right material for different uses, checks its quality, and predicts how it will behave under normal forces. By measuring things like how much it stretches (ultimate tensile strength), how much it changes in size (maximum elongation), and how much it gets thinner (reduction in area), we can learn about other properties like Young's modulus, Poisson's ratio, yield strength, and how the material gets harder to stretch (strain-hardening). For most simple materials, uniaxial testing is enough, but for more complex ones like composites and textiles, biaxial testing is needed. 
STOLports were special airports built for planes that need short runways, like those with small engines. They were popular in the 80s when London City airport had restrictions. These airports had short runways, usually less than 5000 feet, and could only handle certain types of planes, usually smaller ones with limited fuel. In the US, they just call these short runway airports, and the term STOLport isn't used much anymore. 
Trickle valves, also called vacuum valves, are used in factories to keep a dust collector's bottom clean while letting out the collected dust. They are cheaper than other types of airlocks. Trickle valves don't need electricity to work, which is good for machines like trenchers that need a dust-free space for smooth operation. They were made for this exact job. 
Methyltestosterone, also known by names like Agovirin, Android, and Testred, is a man-made medicine that combines strength-boosting and male hormone effects. It helps treat low testosterone levels in men and has other medical uses. Some people, especially athletes and bodybuilders, use it without a doctor's permission to improve their appearance or performance. Methyltestosterone was created in 1935, right after scientists found testosterone. Although it's not as popular as some other similar medicines, doctors still prescribe it today. 
The Belling-Lee connector, also called the IEC 61169-2 type 9,52 connector, is a popular choice for TV antenna connections in Europe and Australia. It's often referred to as a PAL antenna connector, IEC antenna connector, or simply TV aerial plug. There's also a special mini-series called the Kakashi Chronicles before Part II. An anime version by Studio Pierrot and TV Tokyo aired from October 3, 2002, to February 8, 2007, with a separate continuation, Part II, after that.

Another series called Pyu to Fuku! Jaguar was also published in the same magazine from 2000 to 2010, and it was turned into an anime film and a live-action movie in 2008.

There's also an anime version made by Xebec, with a trailer out in 2016, and a TV series adaptation by Pierrot that started in 2017.

They collected ten bound volumes from October 2004 to October 2007.

Question: This work of literature _______ , known by its Greek title Oedipus Tyrannus was argued by Sigmund Freud to be one of the greatest works of world literature in his 1928 article.  

 Passage: 
Sigmund Freud wrote an introduction called Dostoevsky and Parricide for a book about Fyodor Dostoevsky's famous novel, The Brothers Karamazov. The book came out in 1928. Oedipus Rex, also known as Oedipus the King, is a famous play by Sophocles. It was first performed a long, long time ago, around 429 BC. At that time, people just called it Oedipus. Later, they added Tyrant to the title to tell it apart from another play called Oedipus at Colonus. In ancient times, tyrant meant a leader, not necessarily a bad guy.
Sigmund Freud wrote a book called The Interpretation of Dreams in 1899. In it, he talked about how our unconscious mind affects our dreams and introduced the idea of the Oedipus complex. He kept updating the book and added a big part in the third edition where he focused on the literal meaning of dream symbols, inspired by Wilhelm Stekel. Freud considered this kind of understanding a rare achievement. 
Peter Gay's biography of Sigmund Freud, titled Freud: A Life for Our Time, was released in 1988. It builds upon information from Ernest Jones' earlier work, The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud from 1953, but includes fresh details. The book garners positive reviews, but also faces criticism from those who doubt the validity of psychoanalysis. 
Hamlet, a character from Shakespeare's play created in the early 1600s, is widely known, copied, and studied. It significantly impacted psychology through Sigmund Freud's work on the Oedipus complex. This play has had a strong influence on literature overall. In fact, Hamlet's character is so iconic that it has influenced people's attitudes and even turned into a common term used in everyday language. 
In 1965, philosopher Paul Ricœur wrote a book called Freud and Philosophy: An Essay on Interpretation about the famous psychologist Sigmund Freud. This book is sometimes compared to another work by Jürgen Habermas. While some people have praised Ricœur's work, others believe he misunderstands Freud's ideas. 
Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson's book, The Assault on Truth, claims that Freud deliberately ignored his theory that some mental health issues, like hysteria, could be caused by childhood sexual abuse. He did this because he didn't want to accept that kids could be victims of abuse by their own family. Masson knew this because he had access to some of Freud's private letters while working at the Sigmund Freud Archives. The book, first published in 1984, has had updated versions later on. 
Richard Webster's book Why Freud Was Wrong (first published in 1995, with updated editions in 1996 and 2005) critiques Sigmund Freud and psychoanalysis. He claims that Freud became like a religious figure, and psychoanalysis is more like a religious tradition than a science, based on Judaeo-Christian beliefs. Webster supports Gilbert Ryle's ideas from The Concept of Mind (1949) and criticizes other authors who discuss Freud. The book is well-regarded for its brilliance and impact on the ongoing debate about psychoanalysis, but it has faced criticism for its research and argumentation. 
Peter Swales, a Welsh historian who worked with the Rolling Stones, is known for his research on psychoanalysis. He uncovered the real names of some people who were treated by Sigmund Freud early on, using clues that took 25 years to find. His work is mentioned in a 1998 article and a book called In The Freud Archives. The book talks about disagreements between Swales, the book's authors, and another researcher named Jeffrey Masson, who sued the magazine for writing about him. 
Ernest Jones wrote a biography about Sigmund Freud called The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud. This book became very well-known and popular when it first came out in three parts between 1953 and 1957. Later, a shorter version was made by Lionel Trilling and Steven Marcus in 1961. At first, the book was praised, but now some people say that Ernest Jones showed too much admiration for Freud in his biography.

Sorbaria is a group of about 9 flowering plant species that are part of the Rosaceae family. 
Goldenrods, which belong to the Solidago genus in the aster family, are a group of about 100 to 120 flowering plants. They originally come from North America, including Mexico, but some are also found in South America and Eurasia. People have even taken some American goldenrod species to Europe and other regions.
The showy goldenrod, Solidago speciosa, is a type of flowering plant related to the sunflower family. It can be found growing in central Canada, particularly in the province of Ontario, and also across the eastern and central United States. You'll spot it from the Atlantic coast all the way to the Great Plains, which includes states like Maine, Georgia (excluding Delaware), Texas, Nebraska, and the Dakotas. 
Brintonia is a special type of plant that belongs to the sunflower family. It has only one species called Brintonia discoidea. People often call it the rayless mock goldenrod. This plant grows naturally in the southeastern part of the United States, including states like Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, and Mississippi. 
Curtis' goldenrod, also known as mountain decumbent goldenrod, is a type of plant in the sunflower family that grows in the eastern US, specifically in states like Pennsylvania, Mississippi, and Alabama. It mostly thrives in the southern Appalachian Mountains. 
Solidago elongata, often known as West Coast Canada goldenrod or Cascade Canada goldenrod, is a type of flowering plant from the sunflower family that grows naturally in North America. You can find it mainly in western Canada, the western United States, and northwest Mexico, including places like British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, California, and Baja California. It thrives in mountain ranges such as the Coast Ranges, Sierra Nevada, and Cascades. Some populations are also spotted in Nevada and Idaho. 
Ouachita Mountain goldenrod, a type of flowering plant in the aster family, is native to North America and can only be found in the Ouachita Mountains at the border between Arkansas and Oklahoma in the United States. This plant has a very restricted geographic location. 
Wrinkleleaf goldenrod, also known as rough-stemmed goldenrod, is a type of flowering plant from the sunflower family. It can be found in many areas of North America, including eastern and central Canada from Newfoundland to Ontario, and the eastern and central United States from Maine to Wisconsin and Iowa, all the way down to Florida and Texas. 
Bog goldenrod, known as Solidago uliginosa, is a type of flowering plant from the sunflower family. It grows in eastern Canada, from Nunavut to Newfoundland and Manitoba, and also in the eastern United States, including the Great Lakes region, Northeast, and the Appalachian Mountains down to northeastern Georgia. Although there were once reports of it in Alabama, those populations have likely disappeared. 
The rock goldenrod, also known as riverbank goldenrod, is a type of plant that belongs to the sunflower family. It is native to North America and mainly grows in the eastern part of the United States, specifically in states like Maryland, Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee. Although it used to be found in Indiana and Pennsylvania too, those populations have sadly disappeared.

Republican Sinn Féin, often abbreviated as RSF, is an Irish political party that focuses on republicanism. They believe they are connected to the Sinn Féin party started in 1905. Question: What act for Innocent Records achieved Platinum sales and shares its name with a primary color in the RGB color model? 

 Passage: 
Blue is a color that falls between violet and green on the light spectrum. Our eyes see blue when we look at light with a wavelength between 450 and 495 nanometers. The bluer the light, the shorter its wavelength and closer it is to violet. On the other hand, longer wavelengths make blue appear more green. There's a specific shade of pure blue with a wavelength of 470 nanometers. In art and color theory, blue is considered one of the primary colors, along with red and yellow. Mixing red and blue creates violet, while blue and yellow mix to form green. In the technology world, blue is a primary color too, used in the RGB color model for computer screens and televisions to produce all the colors. 
Innocent Records was a special pop music label made by EMI's Virgin Records to work with their artists who liked pop music more. After the Spice Girls became very popular, Virgin Records wanted to focus on pop music too. They brought Hugh Goldsmith from RCA, who helped Take That become very successful, to start his own part of Virgin Records. He signed Billie Piper and Martine McCutcheon, plus some dance groups like Todd Terry. The label kept doing well until the mid-2000s, with artists like Atomic Kitten and Blue selling lots of records.
ProPhoto RGB is a special color space created by Kodak for photography. It has a very wide range of colors, almost 90% of all possible colors and all commonly seen real-world colors. It's even bigger than other wide-gamut color spaces. The choice of colors helps with color accuracy when adjusting images. However, there's a downside - about 13% of the colors are not real and can't be seen. 
The YCoCg color model is a type that simplifies an RGB color space by turning it into three parts: Y (luma), Cg (chrominance green), and Co (chrominance orange). It's widely used in video and image compression systems like H.264, HEVC, JPEG XR, and Dirac because it's easy to calculate, gives good results during compression, and can be converted to and from RGB with fewer data requirements compared to other color models. 
A color space is a way to organize and represent colors, whether on paper or digitally. It helps ensure that colors look the same every time they're reproduced. Color spaces can be simple, like Pantone with specific colors and names, or complex, like NCS, Adobe RGB, or sRGB, which use math to describe colors. A color model is a theoretical way to describe colors as numbers, but it's not useful without a connection to a real-world color space. For example, Adobe RGB and sRGB are two color spaces based on the RGB model. When creating a color space, people often use CIELAB or CIEXYZ, which cover all colors the human eye can perceive. 
HCL is a color space that combines features from cylindrical translations like HSL and HSV, which are similar to RGB but better for human perception in noisy environments. However, HSL and HSV don't match human perception of color brightness, while L*a*b* aligns with how we see colors, but has issues with hue accuracy, especially in blue. 
RGBA is a term that combines red, green, and blue colors along with an extra channel called alpha. It's an extension of the RGB model, which helps with blending or combining colors (called alpha compositing) using a value between 0 and 1. The alpha channel allows for more precise control over transparency. The color itself comes from any RGB color space, but the alpha channel was created by Catmull and Smith in the 1970s for this purpose. 
Brown is a color that comes from mixing different shades in various ways. In printing, it's made by combining red, black, and yellow or red, yellow, and blue. On screens, it's formed by a mix of red and green. We see brown a lot in nature, like in wood, soil, and people's hair, eyes, and skin. It's often associated with dark wood, healthy soil, but also with simple things like rustic materials, poop, and being poor. Many people in Europe and the US don't like the color brown the most. 
The RGB color model is a way to create many colors by adding red, green, and blue light. These three colors, which are called primary, work together to make a wide range of hues. That's why it's called RGB. 
An RGB color space is a system that uses red, green, and blue colors to create other colors. Each RGB color space has specific colors for red, green, and blue, and together they form a triangle of possible colors. To fully describe an RGB color space, you also need to mention the color of white and a curve called gamma correction. As of 2007, sRGB is the most commonly used RGB color space.

The Calumet Downtown Historic District is a special area in Calumet, Michigan. It's located where 5th and 6th Streets meet, between Scott and Pine Streets. This area is also called the Red Jacket Downtown Historic District because that was the old name of the town. It's a part of two bigger historic places: the Calumet Historic District, which is a national landmark, and the Keweenaw National Historical Park. The Glimmerglass Historic District is a special area in New York, near a place called Cooperstown. It's pretty big, covering 15,000 acres and goes through three towns (Otsego, Springfield, and Middlefield) and the village of Cooperstown. This area is all about Otsego Lake and the things around it. The Elmwood Historic District-East is a special area in Buffalo, New York, with lots of old buildings and houses. It's in a neighborhood called Elmwood Village. It's important because it has many well-preserved buildings from the early 1900s. This place is important because it has 384 buildings, 20 sites, and 36 structures that are considered historic. There are also two other smaller historic areas, Atoka and Rectortown, that are a part of it.

Baron MacGregor of Pulham Market, born on February 14, 1937, is a politician from the UK. King's College London, also known as King's or KCL, is a public university in London, England. It was founded in 1829 by King George IV and the Duke of Wellington and is considered the fourth oldest university in the country. Initially, it was a part of the University of London, which it helped create in 1836. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, King's expanded by joining with other schools and colleges, such as Queen Elizabeth College, Chelsea College of Science and Technology, the Institute of Psychiatry, Guy's and St Thomas' Hospitals, and the Florence Nightingale School of Nursing and Midwifery.
Pulham Market and Pulham St Mary are small villages located about 9 miles north of Diss in Norfolk, England. In 2001, they had a population of 999 people living in 443 houses. However, this number slightly decreased to 977 by the time of the 2011 census. The total area these villages cover is 12.08 square kilometers. 
John MacGregor was a Scottish-Canadian soldier who bravely fought in both World Wars. He was so honored that he received the Victoria Cross, which is the top award for showing great courage when facing enemies, given to British and Commonwealth soldiers. 
The University of St Andrews Boat Club, which started in 1965, is a rowing team connected to the University of St Andrews. They are part of the University's Athletic Union and race in events like the Head of the River Race in London, the British University Championships, and Henley Royal Regatta. They follow rules by Scottish Rowing and use the code 'SAU'. 
The Prior of St Andrews was in charge of an Augustinian group of priests in St Andrews Cathedral Priory, Scotland. This group was started by King David I in 1140 with help from Nostell Priory in Yorkshire. At first, the prior might have answered to the bishop, but by the 13th century, the priests chose their own prior. By the end of the century, there was no longer a competing group called the Culdees, and the native priests formed their own church. 
St Andrews Links, located in the town of St Andrews, Fife, Scotland, is known as the birthplace of golf. It boasts one of the oldest courses dating back to the 1500s. Today, there are seven public courses, including the famous Old Course, considered one of the best and most traditional. The Old Course and other links are managed by St Andrews Links Trust, a charity. Additionally, St Andrews is home to the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, a highly esteemed club that used to make golf rules until 2004. 
The University of St Andrews, often called St Andrews University or simply St Andrews, is a very old British school for studying and doing research. It's in a place called St Andrews in Scotland, near a region called Fife. It's the oldest university in Scotland and the third-oldest in the world where people speak English, after Oxford and Cambridge. This special school started between 1410 and 1413 when a group of church leaders from Augustinian religion got permission from a Pope living in a different city called Avignon. 
The Archdeaconry of St Andrews was a part of the larger St Andrews diocese, which had two main areas. The Archdeacon of St Andrews, who reported to the Bishop of St Andrews, oversaw this specific area. Back in the Middle Ages, the Archdeaconry consisted of five groups called deaneries. Together, these deaneries had 124 churches. The five deaneries were Mearns (14 churches), Angus (38 churches), Gowrie (20 churches), Fife (28 churches), and Fothriff (24 churches).

The Jeep Cherokee is a series of cars made by Jeep. It started as a smaller version of the Jeep Wagoneer, then became a small SUV, and now it's a crossover SUV. The name comes from the Cherokee Native American tribe. This name has been used since 1974, and it even led to the creation of the very popular Jeep Grand Cherokee, which was supposed to be part of the Cherokee series at first.

With Galo's leadership, they fought back against Limahong. Eventually, Juan de Salcedo, who brought 300 Ilocano Warriors from Ilocos, joined the battle and defeated Limahong. Question: What produces the hormone that promotes sodium retention in the distal nephron? 

 Passage: 
Angiotensin is a hormone that narrows blood vessels, making blood pressure go up. It's part of a system in our body that some medicines target to lower blood pressure. Angiotensin also makes another hormone called aldosterone. Aldosterone helps the kidneys hold onto more sodium, which contributes to higher blood pressure. 
Aldosterone is a hormone produced by the adrenal gland that helps the body keep sodium and balance potassium levels. It's important for maintaining blood pressure and water balance. When it doesn't work properly, it can cause health problems like heart and kidney issues. It works differently from a hormone called atrial natriuretic hormone, which does the opposite.
The sodium-chloride symporter, also called NCC or NCCT, is a special protein in our kidneys that helps take in sodium and chloride from the tubular fluid into the cells of the distal convoluted tubule. This protein belongs to a group called SLC12 cotransporters. In humans, our body has this protein from a gene called SLC12A3, which is found on chromosome 16q13. 
The loop of Henle is a part of a kidney called a nephron. It starts from the first part of the nephron called the proximal convoluted tubule and goes to the second part, the distal convoluted tubule. A German scientist named Friedrich Henle found this loop. Its main job is to help make a special concentration in the middle part of the kidney called the medulla. 
Low pressure receptors, also known as volume receptors, are found in specific parts of the veins, lungs, and heart. They sense changes in the pressure of the blood vessels when they're not full (less than 60mmHg). These receptors help control the release of hormones like antidiuretic hormone (ADH), renin, and aldosterone. When the pressure in the upper heart chamber (atrium) is high, these hormones are released less. This leads to more urine being produced, which helps lower blood pressure. At the same time, stretching of the atrial receptors triggers the release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), which encourages the body to remove more water and salt through urine. 
Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is a health issue where the body has too much acid because the kidneys can't make the urine as acidic as it should be. When blood goes through the kidneys, it filters out waste and exchanges important things like salts and acids. In RTA, the kidneys either don't absorb enough alkaline bicarbonate ions early on (in the proximal tubule) or don't release enough acidic hydrogen ions later on (in the distal tubule). This leads to a problem called metabolic acidosis. RTA is for people whose kidneys work fine but have trouble with urine acidity. There are different types of RTA, each with its own set of symptoms and causes. 
The ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney is located after the loop's sharp turn, following the descending limb. It has two parts: a thin and a thick section, with the thick part also called the distal straight tubule, which comes before the distal convoluted tubule. 
Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is a system in the kidneys that helps regulate how well the glomerulus filters blood. When there's too much sodium chloride in the kidney's tubules, cells called macula densa release a substance called adenosine. This starts a chain reaction that adjusts the glomerular filtration rate to a healthy level. It's one way the kidneys keep things in balance. 
Sylvia Agnes Sophia Tait, born on January 8, 1917, and passed away on February 28, 2003, was an English biochemist and endocrinologist. She is best known for her collaboration with her husband, James Francis Tait, from 1948 until her death. They made significant contributions to science by discovering aldosterone, a hormone crucial for regulating blood pressure. This hormone helps conserve sodium, release potassium, maintain water balance, and elevate blood pressure. It is believed to cause about 15% of high blood pressure cases. Their partnership was considered one of the most successful in husband-wife scientific collaboration, as mentioned in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. 
Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) is the first type of kidney problem where the body has trouble making enough acid in the urine. This happens because the cells in the kidney that should make acid aren't working properly. This can be caused by different things and results in urine that isn't as acidic as it should be, usually not getting below a pH of 5.3.
